description: Part 2 of complaint...instead of the officer being polite to me as I had apologized, he opted to dig in and degrade me with inappropriate comments. Why can't the police just be polite to people who have admitted an error but state that something is not clear? How hard is it to find signs that say "no left," etc.? Please instruct your officers to actually work (and not chitchat while ignoring traffic) and be better at posting clear signs. Cones have different meanings. A sign is a clear statement. Police should be engaging with the community, not angry people spitting out inappropriate statements. Fix this.

The South Bay construction area is a mess. There are no clear signs, like ( not left turn, etc.) I drove into the plaza , and went to take a left turn. There were haphazardly placed traffic cones with NO signs. The cones were placed such that any driver could have assumed that a large opening between the other tightly spaced cones meant a left turn was ok, esp since there were NO SIGNS. The police officer in the picture was busy chatting with workers rather than directing traffic. I tried to get his attention to no avail. As soon as I turned left, it was clear to me that I had erred. The police officer immediately started getting angry with me, despite the fact that I had just said "I apologize  I think I made an error." His response was "what, the cones weren't an obvious sign," to which I said "no." And then despite my preemptive apology, he continued to make derogatory comments at me. He's being paid to direct traffic, not to chat, and as a default be polite to people (cont.)...

This is for the A-1 neighborhood policing liason.  

There is a significant homeless and panhandler issue that continues at the corner of Portland Street and Causeway St. Mostly this is all in front of the same building on the corner. Is there anything we can do with the property owner to encourage more security or lighting etc?

We have high number of new residents in the area and this situation is a detriment.  Not to mention it's affect on local businesses that rely on residents and Garden event attendees.

Tonight for example at 8:30pm:

1 homeless person sitting on (and blocking) the sidewalk at Subway on Portland since at least 4p.

5 panhandlers are loitering outside the 7-Eleven blocking the sidewalk.

5 more are loitering and trespassing in the adjacent doorway at the defunct store, with open containers.

This is sad but also disgusting - especially given the closure of the opposite sidewalk for construction - so everyone has to walk thru this gauntlet of gross to get to work or home
Please do not give a permit to Nazis and hate groups to march in Boston this weekend.

I don't feel safe walking by the picnic bench at the corner of Warwick and Greenwich Street 02120. 

I get cat called a lot there. These people don't live in the neighborhood. One time a man cat called me, I'm not sure if he specifically followed me, but I didn't go to my house because my door opened to the street. He was behind me the whole time going home asking me questions. I walked to tropical foods. Can you give that corner a little extra attention? That picnic bench is a problem.

Safety:

Everyday I drive though the intersection of melnea cass and mass Ave and it gets worse and worse. A man tried my door the other day. I don't shop at target in South Bay anymore. I go to Somerville or Watertown.

I know there were few options after the long Island bridge collapsed. But I hate this. I hate feeling so vulnerable. At the very least can we have more of a police presence? Or do something to help these people? 

I miss my target and supermarket.  I love my city, but I hate this.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following. Verizon plans on offering FIOS to the  residents of Dorchester. Before they can install the conduit, they need to check the existing conduit to see if the new fiber can be installed. This is called  occupancy work and it is done between manholes.  No digging is involved. If they determine there are sections blocked then they need to install new conduit.   That is what you are seeing on your street. In order to have the best final paving product, the city allows the utility company to leave the base course down low for a few days to allow the lift to set up properly in preparation for the final top course. What you observed was the repair in the binder base course phase. The top course is scheduled to be done  soon. The Inspector will make sure that  on the no parking signs  the dates are accurate on when they are coming back  to perform the top course. This will allow you to monitor when you can and cannot park. We will talk to Verizon and make sure they are adhering to that requirement 100% of the time. We apologize for the inconvenience the work caused. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector states that after the Verizon contractor installs the conduit and backfills the excavation he places a base mix of hot mix asphalt. Within a few days they come back and place the top course of hot mix asphalt. The are in question was topped yesterday and is now level.  For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.

This had not been an issue for the 20 plus years prior to the erroneous marking. Eliot Street is being repaved. status_notes: Case Resolved.  Dear Constituent,. N.Star Electric responding to an electric  conduit damaged by a contractor working on another project had to pull an emergency permit to rectify. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work caused. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Construction Inspection Unit (CIU). Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
